newsitem.title: INDIA: Chidambaram measures fail to cheer Indian markets.
newsitem.headline: Chidambaram measures fail to cheer Indian markets.

text.p: Incentives announced by Finance Minister P. Chidambaram failed to cheer Indian stock markets on Monday but analysts said investors expected more measures when the minister wraps up a delayed budget debate later this week.
"The incentives aren't of much immediate use to investors so the market is unlikely to run away," said a trader at a foreign brokerage.
On Friday, Chidambaram removed a 30 percent ceiling on investment in debt by foreign institutional investors.

He exempted investments in mutual funds from capital gains tax, upped the ceiling marginally on tax-spared dividend income and doubled the limit for bank advances against shares to one million rupees ($280,112).

But market reaction was muted with traders saying the relief measures fell below expectations. In afternoon trade on Monday, the 30-stocks Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) index was trading 30.15 points or 0.86 percent lower at 3477.92 in low volumes.
The benchmark index has fallen about 300 points or some eight percent since India's budget announcements on July 22.
"There are no one-time or magic solutions," Chidambaram told parliament in the first stage of his budget reply on Friday.
"But I am persuaded that there is urgent need to perk up market sentiment since a good part of market behaviour is based on psychology and sentiment," he said.
Chidambaram will address parliament again this week before the budget for 1996/97 (April-March) is put to the vote.
Brokers are expecting him to dilute a controversial 12.9 percent minimum alternate tax on profits of high-growth companies and offer other tax incentives.
"There are other things that he could do and other things that he is likely to do," said Shaun Browne, equity capital markets director at HSBC James Capel.
"But the whole philosophy of the Indian liberalisation process has been gradually, gradually, softly, softly," he said.
Economists said the finance minister could not be expected to announce radical measures as he had to work within the limits of a 13-party ruling coalition.
"Within the constraints he's doing an excellent job," said Arup Raha, senior economist at Lehman Brothers in Hong Kong.
In its latest strategy report, Lehman Brothers said it was overweight on the Indian market from a 12-month perspective.

"The situation currently is that liquidity is ample and relative yields are moving in favour of equities from a domestic investor perspective and with a forecast decline in interest rates and a pick-up in economy later this year," Lehman said.

"The outlook for equities is positive," the report said, forecasting a 12-month target of 4750 points for the Bombay index, representing an upside of 33 percent in rupee terms and 21 percent in dollar terms.
